item.title: DSI Kick Off Meeting & Intro to R files
item.description: Introduction to the DSI slide deck. Materials Program installation, setup, preferences NOT COVERED FULLY DURING WORKSHOP Hands on Introduction to R - Exploring the Data Science Community in Chico. [Download R code] to download the source code for today. Opened in a browser window? Right click & “save as” or “save link as” Save this file to an easy to find place. Desktops are nice.

item.title: Data Visualization using ggplot2
item.description: Objective Grammer of Graphics Data One categorical variable Barchart One numeric variable Histograms and densities Boxplots Quantile-Quantile plots Two categorical variables Grouped barchart Mosaic plots Two numeric variables Scatterplots One numeric and one categorical Overlaid density plots. Paneled histograms Two numerical and one categorical Scatterplots with color Stratified scatterplots with paneling One numerical and two categorical Grouped boxplots Grouped boxplots with paneling Objective In this workshop you will explore data through visual tools using ggplot.

item.title: Data Visualization using ggplot2
item.description: Preparation To get the most out of this workshop you should have the following installed on your laptop: R Version 3.3+ with installed packages: ggplot2, ggmap, MASS optional packages: waffle, scales R Studio version 1.1+ Introduction Visualizing your data is hands down the most important thing you can learn to do. Seeing is critical to understanding. There are three audiences in mind when creating data visualizations:

item.title: Exploring your data with R
item.description: Learning Objectives In this workshop you will learn and practice the following: How to get data into R from a variety of places including the web, from excel, from a CSV file and from a simple text file. How to start looking at your data using tables and simple plots Identifying problems in the data such as missing data or numbers stored as characters Pre-Requirements / Setup A laptop with R (v3.

item.title: Getting Started with Python & Jupyter Notebooks
item.description: Materials Workshop slides [Python Notebook version of slides](/event/setup_python/Python for Windows 10.ipynb) Post workshop updates (by Robin Donatello) Grant led us through how to install Python3 on Windows and OSX using CLI (Command Line Interface). This is a great approach for those who want to get more comfortable with using the command line. For Mac users, the entire process came down to installing 3 programs: homebrew, python3, and jupyter. That is because it’s built on a Unix system.

item.title: Preparing Data for Analysis using R
item.description: Are Your Data Tidy? Or, untidy? Before data can be modeled, analyzed or interpreted… …data must be accessible in meaning-laden forms. Annually, many Analysts around the globe report expending up to 80% of the effort and duration of an investigation in “wrangling” and “tidying” data into a “shape” that enables thoughtful, economical analysis. Does this sound like one of your projects? In this fast-paced Preparing Data for Analysis Workshop, you’ll learn techniques to succeed with—as well as avoid-or remedy—important considerations affecting many datasets; such as:

item.title: Statistical analysis functions using R
item.description: Learning Objectives In this workshop you will learn and practice the following: How to conduct a handful of statistical analysis techniques using R Note: This workshop does not cover the Statistical Methodology or theory behind these statistical procedures. This workshop assumes that you have checked model assumptions and have chosen the most appropriate model for the research question being analyzed. Pre-Requirements / Setup A laptop with R (v3.

item.title: Using Python for Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Materials HTML version of the notebook Python Notebook
